abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is unsatisfactory,
            and, although sustainability is likely, the
            Government's reluctance to proceed with privatization
            of state banks, and insurance companies - based on the
            strong state dominance in these two major sub-sectors -
            raises concerns on the long term sustainability of the
            financial sector. The key lessons address primarily, the
            inappropriate decision making process, particularly, the
            political weakness, and reluctance to bring about reform
            measures, for although there was an awareness on the need
            for reform among financial officials, the absence of
            committed efforts hindered the opportunity to forge the
            reform program. Furthermore, the central coordinating unit
            within the Central Bank, with representation from the
            Ministry of Finance and Planning, was ill conceived, and
            inadequate to mandate reform measures. In addition, the
            absence of a reform framework for the financial sector, was
            conducive to a politically biased, and ad-hoc approach to
            reform. Under these circumstances, the Bank should require
            the government to set up a strong coordinating unit, to
            ensure an effective, and continuous follow-up.
